quoteLast: we anchored in 20 fathoms on hard sand, the south part of _Ilha Verde_, bearing E. and the Cape of Sierra Leona, which is a low point, N. by E. about eight leagues distant.
title: A General History and Collection of Voyages and Travels — Volume 08
author: Kerr, Robert, 1755-1813

quoteFirst: How he had been studying English on the voyage up! He wanted to be a great linguist, and had begun in good earnest. He said "good mornin'" as boldly as possible
quoteLast: , and invariably spoke of the women of America as "him." He had an insane desire to spell, and started spelling-matches with everybody, at the most inappropriate hours and inconvenient places.
title: South-Sea Idyls
author: Stoddard, Charles Warren, 1843-1909

quoteFirst: corps fell right on the centre of the French line (Amanvillers), and a most desperate encounter began, superior control, as before, ceasing after the guns had opened fire. Prince Frederick Charles, however, a little farther north, again asserted his tactical ability, and
quoteLast: he brought into position no less than five army corps for the final attack. The sudden collapse of French resistance, due to the frontal attack of the Guards (St Privat) and the turning movement of the Saxons (Roncourt), rendered the use of this mass unnecessary, but the resolution to use it was there.
title:
Encyclopaedia Britannica, 11th Edition, "Franciscans" to "French Language"
Volume 11, Slice 1
author: Various

quoteTime: about seven o'clock in the evening
quoteLast: when we arrived. The lady of the house, surrounded by a most amiable young family and some friends of the house, gave us a friendly welcome. A refreshing beverage, consisting of almond and rose water, was handed round, and ten minutes afterwards a dinner was served in the best European style.
title:
Diaries of Sir Moses and Lady Montefiore, Volume 2 (of 2)

quoteFirst: During my inquiries on this subject, I visited Church-lane, Bloomsbury, to see a street-seller,
quoteLast: . Since the alterations in St. Giles’s, Church-lane has become one of the most crowded places in London.

quoteFirst: And until the day of his arrival she was very restless. A second telegram came on the morning of that day to tell her he expected to be at Woodlea by

quoteTime: about seven o’clock in the evening

quoteLast: his knock was heard at the door. Miss Stanbury was sitting in the small up-stairs parlour, dressed in her second best gown, and was prepared with considerable stiffness and state for the occasion. Dorothy was with her, but was desired in a quick voice to hurry away the moment the knock was heard, as though old Barty would have jumped from the hall door into the room at a bound.
title: He Knew He Was Right
author: Trollope, Anthony, 1815-1882

quoteLast: Lady Sellingworth was sitting alone in her drawing-room. Sir Seymour Portman had been with her for an hour and had left her at half past six, believing that she was going to spend one of her usual solitary evenings, probably with a book by the fire.
title: December Love
author: Hichens, Robert, 1864-1950

quoteTime: About seven o’clock in the evening
quoteLast: he hurried off to Southwark, and enquired of the porter at the White Hart whether Captain Aglionby was within.  The captain had left a week before, said the porter, in company with a tall, bent, shabby old gentleman. Sherebiah’s worst fears were realized.
title: The Adventures of Harry Rochester: A Tale of the Days of Marlborough and Eugene

quoteFirst: While this was going on (following Smith's own account),* "the brethren began to prophesy blessings upon each other's heads, and cursings upon the enemies of Christ who inhabit Jackson County, Missouri, and continued prophesying and blessing and sealing them, with hosannah and amen, until
quoteLast: The bread and wine were then brought in.

quoteFirst: Determined that there should be nothing in his conduct towards his mother resembling sullenness, he had occasionally spoken to her on passing matters, and would take no notice of the brevity of her replies. With the same resolve to keep up a show of conversation he said,
quoteTime: about seven o'clock in the evening
quoteLast: , "There's an eclipse of the moon tonight. I am going out to see it." And, putting on his overcoat, he left her.

quoteFirst: Passed through woods and crossed river several times.

quoteTime: about seven o'clock in the evening
quoteLast: , when Forster thus exposed himself to the inclemency of the weather.  But a few weeks before how beautiful were the evenings at this hour; the sun disappearing beyond the distant wave, and leaving a portion of his glory behind him until the stars, in obedience to the divine fiat, were lighted up to "shine by night;" the sea rippling on the sand, or pouring into the crevices of the rocks, changing its hue, as daylight slowly disappeared, to the more sombre colours it reflected, from azure to each deeper tint of grey, until darkness closed in, and its extent was scarcely to be defined by
title: Newton Forster; Or, The Merchant Service
author: Marryat, Frederick, 1792-1848

quoteLast: , one of the French admiral's seconds advanced out of the line, and began a closer engagement with the "Saint George," commanded by Captain Jennings; but, although the "Saint George" had already suffered much, the French ship met with such rough treatment that she had great difficulty in rejoining the line, after the loss of both her captains and many of her men.

quoteLast: word came over the wire to head-quarters that Tettman and Jackson had been safely landed in one of the station houses.
